Energy + Inner Chi

We are Enerchi

We are a collective of community figures, dedicated to sustainable environmental practices and widening educational resource access through technology.

We repair our relationship between ourselves, our communities, technology, the environment. We often focused on technological literacy and youth education with an emphasis on environmental education.

Enerchi Initiative is a social venture launched by Pythagoras Ecology and Calgary Community Development.

Building An ecosystem of Care
Environment & Education

Our Goals

1. Remove and mill downed logs from the roadsides, manufacturing LSL, LVL, CLT, plywood, particleboard, plus specialty lumber.

2. Apply our considerable design knowledge and resources in creation of useful wood products which serve learning needs of school age children, then broader for the adult segment.

3. Personal Computer/Internet introduction

4. Job training, jobs, Service learning internships.

5. Employability training and skill building for youth: Soft skills for resume writing, interviewing, Technical literacy skills.

5. Reforestation, planting of diverse trees throughout the community and cities in collaboration with local and state beautification, watershed creation guideline plans.

7. Design and build vertical & community raised bed gardens deploying hydroponic, aeroponic and aquaponics methodologies utilizing wood milled from emergency zones and community greening, Activity-based classes

8. 5,000+sq.ft. homes for youth who are aging out of foster care.

Enerchi today

The priority of the moment: Bridging the Digital Divide

Right now, there is also a pressing need for members in our community to have access to dignified working stations. This is especially the case now that so many must work from home to social distance. We proposed to solve two problems at once: getting rid of the dead trees that cause wildfires, and building desks and table furniture for the community. By using pythagorean geometry, we can laser cut the wood into desks and chairs that can be flat packed and assembled on site. We are working with a consortium of churches and community organizations to put these workstations in places where students can access them.

One with the nature's ecosystems

Our Values

Connection & Complexity

What We Believe In

We believe in some simple things:
Socially responsible, Locally Sourced materials, American-Made Manufacturing, fair wages, Elegant and unique craftsmanship, creating new opportunities for people with high barriers to success.

However, we believe in far more than that. We see personal, environmental, communal and educational wellbeing as interconnected elements of holistic wellbeing, and seek to restore the balance between them all. We need to repair our relationship between ourselves, our communities, technology, the environment. Now we are focusing on technological literacy and youth education with an emphasis on environmental education. In this moment of rapid changing educational environment and rapid changes to come from environmental destruction and technology we need to prepare our children to face the huge challenges ahead.

But this is just the first step on the journey of building that world. We will continue to work towards a world in which all things can be in balance until we reach it.

Our furniture changes what our children perceive they can be.

So much of what we can be is based on what we perceive we can be”

— Joseph Loeb, Founder

Joseph Loeb is a lifelong entrepreneur, with a vision for how technology is an essential avenue for democratizing opportunity. The year was 1992, during the riots from the death of Latasha Harlins, a 13 year old black girl who was shot after leaving a corner store, that Loeb’s passion for technology and community was seeded. She was the “last straw” in these Rodney King riots of 1992.

As lifelong resident of Los Angeles, Loeb was at the epicenter of the sirens, the smoke, and the anguish that echoed across the nation that spring. Loeb recounts,

“It's amazing how they could understand the humanity in the perpetrators, but not in us. It was a horrible pain.”

Loeb’s response was to take action, to transgress this energy into action. He thought technology was one of the few areas that could “level the playing field”. He got this idea from the old Mission Impossible movie. One of the characters, Greg Morris, a spy disguised as a tech expert, was called into the government office to fix an IT problem. Little did the government workers know that Greg was actually there to help his espionage team infiltrate. Loeb saw how Greg was able to navigate so seamlessly as a black man, simply because he was a tech expert.

This planted seeds for him that 1) technology is a vIable avenue to equalize opportunities in the workforce for black people and 2) technology can be a revolutionary tool to innovate for the betterment of his community.

Since then, Loeb has done work in building computer labs across the country to democratize access to computer software. For his work in education and technology access, he received the Essence Award in technology along with mogul Bill Gates in 2000.

Our team

Shares what they love about Enerchi

Joseph Loeb

President/CEO

What I love About Enerchi

Keyanna Ortiz-Cedeño

Grant Manager

“Often in social justice oriented spaces we focus on how the overlap of multiple systems compound marginalization. Lack of investment in public education and discriminaiton against employees with criminal records leads to recidivism. Poor forestry practices and climate change increase risk for wildfires. But, with the Enerchi Initiative, we are thinking innovatively about how to intersect potential challenges to create solutions."

Pastor Robert Smith

Counselor

"[I enjoy working with Enerchi because they are committed to] working with empowering and restoring existing inmates, transitioning Foster Youth, expanding affordable housing, and creating purpose-driven innovations with technology."

Margaret Smith

Accountant

“What I love about the Enerchi Initiative is it’s impact on the marginalized populations by enlightening, educating, empowering & inspiring them to their full potential. Also, it’s focus with emphasis on the environment and climate change.”

Merry Moore

Intake and Recruitment Assistant
